Description: John Young on the Moon, with the Lunar Module and Lunar Rover in the background

Artifacts.Description: The deep drill string was separated into two sections of three stems each on the lunar surface (60007, 60006 and 60005) and (60004, 60003, 60002 and 60001bit).
The deep drill string was separated into two sections of three stems each on the lunar surface (60007, 60006 and 60005) and (60004, 60003, 60002 and 60001bit).
The deep drill string was separated into two sections of three stems each on the lunar surface (60007, 60006 and 60005) and (60004, 60003, 60002 and 60001bit).
The deep drill string was separated into two sections of three stems each on the lunar surface (60007, 60006 and 60005) and (60004, 60003, 60002 and 60001bit).
The deep drill string was separated into two sections of three stems each on the lunar surface (60007, 60006 and 60005) and (60004, 60003, 60002 and 60001bit).

Deep core contining samples 60001 through 60007 was drilled at the ALSEP site about 175 m southwest of the LM and 25 m south of the ALSEP central station. The sample area is generally flat with blocks up to 10-15 cm abundant. Deep drill area has the least compacted soil and the highest density of craters in the area. Core stems went easily into the surface.

Deep core contining samples 60001 through 60007 was drilled at the ALSEP site about 175 m southwest of the LM and 25 m south of the ALSEP central station. The sample area is generally flat with blocks up to 10-15 cm abundant. Deep drill area has the least compacted soil and the highest density of craters in the area. Core stems went easily into the surface.

Drive Tube 60009/60010 was taken at Station 10 bout 100 meters southwest of the LM. Samples were taken from the rim of a subdued 60 cm crater. Fragments on the surface are mostly pear sized; none are larger than a few cm. Grain sizes >1mm may have been handled less so friable fragments would be less likely to break apart.

Drive Tube 60009/60010 was taken at Station 10 bout 100 meters southwest of the LM. Samples were taken from the rim of a subdued 60 cm crater. Fragments on the surface are mostly pear sized; none are larger than a few cm. Grain sizes >1mm may have been handled less so friable fragments would be less likely to break apart.
60014 - 60013 is one of the three cores that were collected close to one another (about 50 m apart) at the ALSEP site at Apollo 16

Core drilled on Stone Mountain at Station 4, within one crater diameter of a 15 meter subdued doublet crater. The deep sections of the core may contain the best samples of typical Descartes material. The sample area has a 10-15 degree slope to the northwest. There are a few scattered cobbles 5-10 cm. Scattered craters .5 to several meters in diameter are common in the general area, there is a .5 meter crater just southwest of the drive tube.

Drive tube 64001 / 64002 collected on Stone Mountain at Station 4, within one crater diameter of a 15 meter subdued doublet crater. The deep sections of the core may contain the best samples of typical Descartes material. The sample area has a 10-15 degree slope to the northwest. There are a few scattered cobbles 5-10 cm. Scattered craters .5 to several meters in diameter are common in the general area, there is a .5 meter crater just southwest of the drive tube.

very coarse grained; speculated that "the top of this zone may represent a buried topographic surface". However, this study was based on an interpretation of the Xradiograph, and was not confirmed by the study of the core after extrusion. Schwarz (1994) described the samples during dissection.
contains friable white breccias described by the crew as "caliche - like", and contains abundant fragments <15cm.
walnut-sized particles from soil sample 60050 are what gave the soil a "white" appearance on the lunar surface.
walnut-sized particles from soil sample 60050 are what gave the soil a "white" appearance on the lunar surface.
walnut-sized particles from soil sample 60050 are what gave the soil a "white" appearance on the lunar surface.
walnut-sized particles from soil sample 60050 are what gave the soil a "white" appearance on the lunar surface.
walnut-sized particles from soil sample 60050 are what gave the soil a "white" appearance on the lunar surface.
The sample accompanies rake sample 60510. The sieved portion of 60500 did not include any walnut sized rocks (> 1 cm), however, a large portion remains unsieved.
the surface is mostly coated with micrometeorite craters and is cataclastic anorthosite - of the ferroan variety.
the surface is mostly coated with micrometeorite craters and is cataclastic anorthosite - of the ferroan variety.
the surface is mostly coated with micrometeorite craters and is cataclastic anorthosite - of the ferroan variety.
the surface is mostly coated with micrometeorite craters and is cataclastic anorthosite - of the ferroan variety.
the surface is mostly coated with micrometeorite craters and is cataclastic anorthosite - of the ferroan variety.
Warner et al. (1976) described 60525 as heterogeneous, with half of matrix with poikilitic texture and half with subophitic texture.
dense, aphanitic, coherent rock fragment. It has a high rare-earth-element and major element content characteristic of KREEP (Meyer 1974).
typical glass matrix regolith breccias
typical Apollo 16 soil; coarse-fine particles
coarse-fine particles, contained 33 fragments larger than 1 cm
basaltic impact melt with one large vesicle; coherent, mostly intergranular with olivine and pyroxene confined to intersticies between fine plagioclase laths
tough, light gray rake sample consisting of basaltic impact melt and cataclastic anorthosite; found to be highly aluminous with an age about 4 b.y.
light gray anorthosite, coherent, recrystallized, plagioclaserich rock with minor glass-splash and a few micrometeorite craters. It has not been well studied.
plagioclase-rich, white rock, but it also has high content of REE
poikilitic texture, but the plagioclase chadocrysts have indistinct boundaries.
light colored and must be mostly plagioclase, because it seems large for its weight (low density) and has zap pits with transparent glass linings.
an anorthosite with attached black glass, cataclastic texture and the pyroxenes indicate that this sample is ferroan anorthosite
igneous rock, basaltic texture.
clast-rich impact melt, has one of the highest contents of trace elements in the Apollo 16 collection, and has been dated at 3.94 b.y.
typical glass matrix regolith breccias, glass shards, lithic fragments and mineral fragments in a seriate grain size distribution

fragmental polymict breccia with a low porosity. A wide variety of clasts is present, a mare basalt and a pristine anorthosite being of particular significance. One side of the subangular rock is covered with a smooth dark glass
vesicular fine-grained impact melt with an unusual coloration
small polymict breccias, contains a number of feldspar-rich clasts in a coherent matrix
contains chalky white clasts loosely held by black vesicular glass; cataclastic anorthosite
glass-coated impact-melt breccias
clastrich "glassy impact melt"; has abundant white clasts, thin glass veins and glassy mesostasis

Soil color is listed as light olive gray but mission transcripts state, "I just had a good scoopful, and I lost it. Let me dig out a little - another little trench. There she be. Coming up all white. That's all that's in there John."
contained several white and off-white particles as well as 3 peppered black and white rock fragments that appeared to fit together as one

This is part of a radial sample sequence with 61180, 61160, and 61140. The site is level with fragments 1-10 cm sparse and none larger in the area. Craters <3 m are common; most are subdued but one has a sharp rim.

This is part of a radial sample sequence with 61180, 61160, and 61140. The site is level with fragments 1-10 cm sparse and none larger in the area. Craters <3 m are common; most are subdued but one has a sharp rim.
friable, clastic, seriate and "very light-grey"
friable, clastic, seriate and "very light-grey"
friable, clastic, seriate and "very light-grey"
friable, clastic, seriate and "very light-grey"
friable, clastic, seriate and "very light-grey"
As sorted and described by Phinney et al. (1973) they may all be the same material. Only 61525 has been studied.
As sorted and described by Phinney et al. (1973) they may all be the same material. Only 61525 has been studied.
As sorted and described by Phinney et al. (1973) they may all be the same material. Only 61525 has been studied.
As sorted and described by Phinney et al. (1973) they may all be the same material. Only 61525 has been studied.
contains a large white clast held within a glass matrix, and has a thin glass coating on surface
vesicular chunk of glass with numerous small white clast and micrometeorite craters on one side only.
devitrified glass containing small clasts of plagioclase and feldspathic impact melt breccia
devitrified glass containing small clasts of plagioclase and feldspathic impact melt breccia
coherent dense impact melt with microlites of mafic minerals in aphanitic matrix
has two distinct textures (basalt and poikilitic), separated by a sharp boundary
coherent impact melt breccia; appears to be different from most pokilitic melt rocks at Apollo 16 because the dominant oikocryst is olivine, rather than pyroxene

apparently homogeneous, coherent, hollocrystaline impact melt rock with classic poikilitic texture highly enriched in trace elements and siderophile elements and has been dated at 3.88 b.y., with an exposure history of 153 m.y.
found to be a slowly-cooled plutonic rock (Takeda et al. 1979) with an age of ~4.3 b.y. (Borg et al. 1999).
blocky coherent impact melt rock with numerous micrometeorite pits on one side and none on the other
dark grey microbreccia, cut by a light vein of devitrified glass
Pieces of 63355 have patina and micrometeorite craters

area contains small rocks (2-10 cm) which cover 5% of the surface, fines are less compacted than soil at North Ray crater. Random 1-2 meter fresh to subdued craters are found in the local area. No crater is recognizable in the immediate sample area.
round particle is coherent and appears to be mostly plagioclase
friable breccias with a light brown color and is partially coated with black glass
Phinney et al. (1976) describe these samples together as "tough crystalline breccia".
Phinney et al. (1976) describe these samples together as "tough crystalline breccia".
Phinney et al. (1976) describe these samples together as "tough crystalline breccia".
dark, homogeneous, coherent finegrained impact melt breccias
small fragments of Impact Melt Rock - some with finegrained basaltic texture; there are numerous small relic clasts that are incorporated in the matrix
small fragments of Impact Melt Rock - some with finegrained basaltic texture; there are numerous small relic clasts that are incorporated in the matrix
small fragments of Impact Melt Rock - some with finegrained basaltic texture; there are numerous small relic clasts that are incorporated in the matrix
glass-matrix breccia with abundant small clasts
Rake Sample 63548 contains 63539 and 63586 are fragments of fine-grained, coherent impact melt
coherent impact melt rock with numerous zap pits; has been dated at 3.9 b.y.
Rake Sample 63548 contains 63539 and 63586 are fragments of fine-grained, coherent impact melt
rake sample with numerous micrometeorite cratrers; is coherent and appears to be a homogeneous impact melt rock. It has been dated at 3.84 b.y.
Phinney et al. (1976) describe these samples together as "tough crystalline breccia".
poikilitic impact melt with the bulk composition of KREEP. It has a few micrometeorite zap pits
dark, homogeneous, coherent finegrained impact melt breccias
chunks of dark, vesicular glass with white inclusions
chunks of dark, vesicular glass with white inclusions
small glass sample has relatively large white inclusions
chunks of dark, vesicular glass with white inclusions
chunks of dark, vesicular glass with white inclusions
small glass sample has relatively large white inclusions
chunks of dark, vesicular glass with white inclusions
a fragmental breccia with at least some glass in the matrix
impact melt breccia with regions that have basaltic texture and other areas that are poikilitic, and has numerous micrometeorite craters on the surface
Rake Sample 63548 contains 63539 and 63586 are fragments of fine-grained, coherent impact melt
a coherent impact melt breccia with a poikilitic texture and numerous clasts and has numerous micrometeorite craters on its surface
polymict fragmental breccias, with angular clasts of plagioclase, brown glassy breccias, aphanitic melts and feldspathic granulite.
polymict fragmental breccias, with angular clasts of plagioclase, brown glassy breccias, aphanitic melts and feldspathic granulite.
fine-grained poikilitic texture where pyroxene oikocrysts surround laths of plagioclase. It is clastic and vesicular.
63597 and 63598 are extremely porous poikilitic impact melt breccias
63597 and 63598 are extremely porous poikilitic impact melt breccias

Soil 64420 was collected with breccia 64475 at Station 4A near Cinco B crater, 5 meters from the LRV on the floor of a subdued 15 meter crater. The soil was taken from the bottom of a 25 cm trench. At the sample area, 5-10 cm pebbles are abundant, 20-40 cm cobbles are common and meter size blocks are sparsely scattered. Scattered craters up to several meters in size are common in the general area. This regolith is probably South Ray ejecta mixed with underlying Descartes material.
numerous micrometeorite craters; "black and white" rocks with veins of dark impact melt rock intruding white cataclastic anorthosite
numerous micrometeorite craters; "black and white" rocks with veins of dark impact melt rock intruding white cataclastic anorthosite
Warner et al. (1973) termed 64477 "cataclastic anorthosite to light matrix breccia plus mesostasis-rich basalt".
Ryder and Norman (1980) term 64478 a "glass-coated impact melt". The interior has a poikilitic texture in places

Soil 64500 and rake 64510 were collected at Station 4A in the vicinity of Cinco B crater,. The sample area slopes 10-15 degrees to the northwest off Stone Mountain, surface fragments up to 10 cm are abundant, up to 40 cm are common, up to 1 meter sparse. Scattered craters .5 to several meters are in the general area, very subdued and barely visible smaller craters are in the local area. The gray surface is underlain by a white layer.
large number of glass particles
has a cosmic ray exposure age of 1.9 m.y; a mix of cataclastic ferroan anorthosite with impact melt. In some cases they also have a thick black glass coating
a mix of cataclastic ferroan anorthosite with impact melt. In some cases they also have a thick black glass coating
has zap pits on all surfaces; a mix of cataclastic ferroan anorthosite with impact melt. In some cases they also have a thick black glass coating
micrometeorite craters on all surfaces; majority of the sample is a coherent, medium grey, glassy matrix lithology
chalky white portion and a dark aphanitic portion characteristic of the light and dark lithologies
chalky white portion and a dark aphanitic portion characteristic of the light and dark lithologies
chalky white portion and a dark aphanitic portion characteristic of the light and dark lithologies
chalky white portion and a dark aphanitic portion characteristic of the light and dark lithologies
fine grain mix of chalky white anorthite and dark aphanitic impact melt
chalky white portion and a dark aphanitic portion characteristic of the light and dark lithologies

chalky white portion and a dark aphanitic portion characteristic of the light and dark lithologies
piece of the dark lithology that is part of the abundant dimict breccias from that location; texture is that of a basalt, but since it includes clasts of anorthite, it is an impact melt breccia
complex mix of glass and impact melt
dark coherent aphanitic sample with a few vesicles with abundant olivine oikocrysts and is relatively mafic
poikilitic texture with a network of pyroxene phenocrysts surrounding small laths of plagioclase with zap pits
dark coherent aphanitic sample with a few vesicles with abundant olivine oikocrysts and is relatively mafic
fine-grained irregular basaltic texture with inclusions
old impact melt with unique texture, brownish color and a devitrified glass matrix
relatively mature soil with average grain size 80 microns
relatively mature soil with average grain size 80 microns
impact melt breccia with a coarse poikilitic texture and KREEP-like composition. The age has been determined to be 3.89 � 0.01 b.y.
holocrystalline poikilitic impact melt with a crystallization age of 3.85 b.y.
aluminous basalt with prominent plagioclase laths and an age of 3.84 b.y.
Phinney et al. (1976) refer to 64818 as a "tough crystalline breccia" with 5% vugs and vesicles

large glass object that contains interesting white clasts
greenish gray breccia with a black glass coating
about 8 cm across; abundant micrometeorite pits and patina on this surface;
white rocks with a thin coat of black glass; zap pits on the white surfaces where the black glass has apparently been eroded off
Moderately coherent cataclastic anorthosite; has a "bronze colored" streak
white rocks with a thin coat of black glass; zap pits on the white surfaces where the black glass has apparently been eroded off
Light gray, coherent, poikilitic impact melt , and is rounded and covered with micrometeorite craters
coherent, but it is angular and more aluminous

65700 and 65900 are surface soils to accompany the rake samples at Station 5. The sample area has a mostly sandy surface with no large blocks nearby. Fines in the area are extremely loose.
appears to be soil and rake residue from samples 65501, 65601 and 65701.
Keil et al. (1972) and Ryder and Norman (1981) describe the sample as a friable grey and white breccia with abundant comminuted plagioclase.
small brown soil breccia, seriate grain size distribution, with glass in the matrix
small brown soil breccia, seriate grain size distribution, with glass in the matrix
small brown soil breccia, seriate grain size distribution, with glass in the matrix
small brown soil breccia, seriate grain size distribution, with glass in the matrix

small brown soil breccia, seriate grain size distribution, with glass in the matrix
small brown soil breccia, seriate grain size distribution, with glass in the matrix
glassy object contains relatively large white clasts
glassy object contains relatively large white clasts
coherent crystalline impact melt breccia with poikilitic texture; has be dated at 3.7 b.y.
coherent crystalline impact melt breccia with poikilitic texture
has a texture described as basaltic, rather than poikilitic; contains clasts of plagioclase, so it was a breccia before it crystallized
contains a coarse-grained pink spinel troctolite clast in a crystalline feldspathic impact melt rock; has been dated at 3.97 b.y. by one group and 3.83 b.y. by another.
a coherent, medium grey, polymict breccia with abundant glass in the matrix
appears to have a ribbon of glass interior
chalky white rake sample
basaltic texture, is highly aluminous; has been dated at 3.81 b.y.
65920 is the residue from a rake sample at the same location.
rounded, friable soil breccia
rounded, friable soil breccias
rounded, friable soil breccia
very mature soil with an average grain size of 121 microns
regolith breccia, but has excess 40Ar and has been termed "ancient regolith breccia". 66035 has zap pits on all surfaces so it must have "rolled or jumped" on the regolith.
regolith breccia, but has excess 40Ar and has been termed "ancient regolith breccia".
collected from a small subdued crater on the Cayley Plain near Stone Mountain

fragmental matrix breccia, mostly feldspar, but with a wide range of highland lithologies represented as loose clasts in the matrix; have been dated at 3.9 b.y. and the breccias, itself, has had an exposure to cosmic ray of 51 m.y.
glass-coated crystalline rock with basaltic melt surrounding xenoliths of plagioclase.
white polymict breccia made up of mostly calcic plagioclase and a few relict lithic clasts and has lots of zap pits on top and bottom
According to Lindstrom and Lindstrom (1986), 67415 is a lightly-shocked, granulitic breccia with a cataclastic matrix.
very friable, white polymict feldspathic breccia
a tough purplish-grey, glassy breccia

Reference soil 67840 accompanies rake sample 67510; sample area is in a local north-south swale, the surface is soft and fine; fragments greater than 10 cm are sparse and the crew reported "sinking in on the slopes about 6 inches."
crystalline impact melt
crystalline impact melts
noticeably coarser grain size and less mature compared with other lunar soils probably due to the fact that NRC is only 50 m.y. old
friable, chalky white rock containing lithic fragments of cataclastic anorthosite and feldspathic granulite
friable, chalky white rock containing lithic fragments of cataclastic anorthosite and feldspathic granulite
friable, chalky white rock containing lithic fragments of cataclastic anorthosite and feldspathic granulite
friable, chalky white rock containing lithic fragments of cataclastic anorthosite and feldspathic granulite
friable, chalky white rock containing lithic fragments of cataclastic anorthosite and feldspathic granulite
cataclastic anorthosite
contains unusual clasts, some with abundant melt, some with abundant Fe-rich olivine and ferro-augite; zap pits on the outer surfaces
porous and rounded with a light matrix and both light and dark clasts.
porous and rounded with a light matrix and both light and dark clasts
a friable micropoikilitic impact melt with intrusive glass veins. It has a micrometeorite crater.
igneous texture indicating that it cooled from a liquid, albeit, highly aluminous. It contains a trace of Ni, Ir and Au and has been dated at 3.76 � 0.04 b.y., which makes it a critical sample.
micropoikitiic texture with interlocking oikocrysts of pyroxene surrounding chadocrysts of plagioclase. Ilmenite is concentrated at the boundaries of the pyroxene oikocysts.
glass-laden fragments; Ryder and Norman (1980) reported that 67566 had a "granoblastic" texture. The protolith was clearly a breccia.
glass-laden fragments
glass-laden fragments
glass-laden fragments
The soil is probably derived from North Ray crater ejecta
relatively large friable, white particle about the size, shape and color of a golf ball
coarse-fine particles
has olivine as the main mafic mineral and it may have a high proportion of opaque phases, is rounded and has zap pits on all sides
moderately coherent impact melt breccia with zap pits on one surface
"partly devitrified glass bomb"
glass-cemented aggregates
"glass bomb"
glass-cemented aggregates
relatively unshocked ferroan anorthosite, but have not been dated; angular, chalky white, very homogeneous sample with very finely granular sugary texture
Warren and Wasson (1980) describe 67635, 67636 and 67637 as mildly-shocked "monomict breccia, perhaps slightly less cataclastic than is typical for ferroan anorthosite".
subrounded, chalky-white, homogeneous sample with apparent cataclastic texture and appears to be a piece of 67635.
relatively coherent with lots of zap pits and has glass clasts, and glass in the matrix
is coherent and has a few micrometeorite craters on the surface, found to be chemically "pristine" and to have an old age (4.2 b.y.).
has a micropoikitiic texture with interlocking oikocrysts of pyroxene surrounding chadocrysts of plagioclase

The soil samples from station 11 at North Ray Crater have noticeably coarser grain size and are less mature compared with other lunar soils probably due to the fact that NRC is only 50 m.y. old (Arvidson et al. 1975).
coarse-fine particles
coherent, fine-grained impact melt rock
coherent, fine-grained impact melt rock; reported to have pink spinel as a large clast and is probably more aluminous
abundant clasts of plagioclase set in an aphanitic matrix
abundant clasts of plagioclase set in an aphanitic matrix
glass (?) particles with zaps
vesicular glass breccia with significant clasts, and has the appearance of a "glass bomb". It has zap pits on all sides.
It has zap pits; Stoffler et al. (1981) describe the matrix as "micropoikilitic". Photos of the exterior show what appears to be pink spinel (?) grains (not confirmed).
has a brown color, probably due to glass with abundant plagioclase (An98-90) and plagioclase-rich clasts.
plagioclase with a granuliticpoikilitic texture, Large pyroxene grains completely surround rounded olivine and plagioclase with Ilmenite and metallic Ni-Fe grains found between pyroxene oikocrysts.
small aluminous basalt with measured age of 3.86 b.y. Elongate plagioclase and pyroxene laths are poikilitically enclosed in large olivine. Glassy mesostasis is found adjacent to pyroxene.
Granulitic Breccia with clast of KREEP basalt
small chalky white particle, plagioclase rich breccia, with minerals that seem to have equilibrated - hence it is called "recrystallized".
impact melt with fine-grained subophitic and poikilitic textures, with glass veins
impact melt with fine-grained subophitic and poikilitic textures, with glass veins
a coherent, plagioclase-rich breccia with a granular matrix. It has a measured age of 3.82 b.y.
has a micropoikilitic texture indicating that it is an impact melt breccia

has a KREEP like rare-earth-element pattern with micrometerorite craters. Reimold et al. (1985) noted it was rather unique among Apollo 16 samples in being the only sample with intergranular texture and containing a high amount of mafic mineral clasts.
glass-coated white anorthosite with a blue-green sheen
Steele and Smith (1973) refer to it as a "complex, black and white breccia with some devitrified glass".
mix of dark glass and grey impact melt clasts; age has been determined - 3.8 b.y.
described as a "cinder" by Smith and Steele (1972). Ryder and Norman (1980) noted that it may be a glass coated lithic fragment, but it has never been subdivided or studied.
small lithic fragment had a glass coat that has been partially chipped away by micrometeorite bombardment.
appears to be impact melt breccia, with poikilitic texture, but have not been studied.
appears to be impact melt breccia, with poikilitic texture, but have not been studied.
appears to be impact melt breccia, with poikilitic texture, but have not been studied.
impact melt fragments cemented by a black glass
impact melt fragments cemented by a black glass
mature soil
Coherent, very light gray, shock-melted and cataclastic anorthosite; largely coated with vesicular glass up to 1 cm thick
The outer surface has a thick patina, while the freshly broken surface is hackly
relatively inhomogeneous and apparently not used for cosmic-ray-penetration studies. However, it was determined to have a cosmic ray exposure age of 2.1 m.y.
coherent, medium-gray glassy breccia containing several large, light colored clasts
Coarse-grained, moderately shocked, pristine cataclastic ferroan anorthosite
Fractured spheroid of yellow-green to light brown glass
Glass-bonded polymict breccia; It has not been studied.
coherent impact melt rock with a mostly basaltic texture; there are micrometeorite craters on all sides and some vesicles are obvious; otherwise, it has not been studied.
coherent, dark-matrix soil breccia with abundant white clasts, partially coated with a frothy black glass and has few micrometeorite craters.
Tough, medium gray, poikilitic impact melt that has been thermally metamorphosed
contains a high percentage of glass, with some agglutinate. It also contains a small, but significant, mare component.
chalky white rock
has been crushed and granulated by shock and is penetrated with patches and veins of mafic melt
Poikilitic Impact Melt

large clasts of light-colored cataclastic anorthosite intermixed with dark-colored basaltic impact melt; covered or coated with a thick glass coat on one side. An age of 2.29 m.y. indicates that this rock was derived from South Ray Crater.
aluminous, basaltic impact melt, is coherent and appears to be homogeneous throughout, and has been determined to be 3.96 b.y old by the Ar/Ar plateau technique

complex polymict feldspathic breccia that appears to be intermediate between fragmental breccias and glassy melt breccias, with included abundant rounded patches of brown glass; is ~3.9 b.y. old, with an exposure to cosmic rays for 55 m.y.
one of many coherent, light matrix breccias from Apollo 16 and has about equal amounts of both dark and light aphanitic clasts; has been dated at about 3.8 b.y.
labeled "Rusty Rock"; has abundant zap pits on one side, and is 3.8 b.y., and cosmic ray exposure is 40-80 m.y.
Very friable, light matrix breccia; was found to be 3.95 b.y.
black and white breccia; high trace element content, but has not been dated.

Lunar sample 67075 is very friable. Detailed petrographic description showed that the sample may be a mixture of closely related anorthositic rocks from a layered igneous intrusion, and it has been shown to be 4.47 b.y. old, with about 50 m.y. exposure to cosmic rays
composed of white and grey breccias; both are polymict (Taylor and Mosie 1979), cemented by shock-melted glass and is also cut with thin black glass veins.
thin veins of black glass, texture of fine-grained subophitic basalt
thin veins of black glass, texture of fine-grained subophitic basalt
thin veins of black glass, texture of fine-grained subophitic basalt
exterior surface has a thin brown patina with micrometeorite pits; has been dated at 4.2 b.y. with exposure to cosmic rays for ~ 50 m.y. (age of North Ray Crater).
Irregularly shaped rock with approximately equal amounts of pale gray, fragmental, friable breccia and a coating of frothy, clast-rich glass.

outer surface covered with zap pits; the broken surface contains large vugs and vesicles. 68815 is one of the samples that date the age of South Ray Crater (Drozd et al. 1974; Pepin et al. 1974) and is said to have had a simple exposure history.
a rock that is relatively coarse-grained, shocked cataclastic anorthosite with a flat black glass vein running the length
a friable breccia disaggregated with 1362 freeze - thaw cycles; surface is relatively unpitted and smooth.

fine-grained, clast-rich, polymict breccia made up of clasts of ferroan anorthosite, troctolite, troctolitic anorthosite and noritic anorthosite. To date, it remains poorly characterized, and requires further study. Recently, it was dated at 4.09 � 0.1 b.y. with an exposure to cosmic radiation for about 6 m.y.
a friable, porous, feldspathic breccia. It has not been well-studied.
glass covered, round object with a coarsegrained, highly shocked cumulate interior
actually a polymict breccia, the largest portion is almost pure white and very plagioclase rich. The anorthositic portion is both highly shocked and cataclastic.
glass coated regolith breccia. One side has had the glass coating chipped off by micrometeorite bombardment.

flat rock, about 4 cm thick, top exposed surface covered with micrometeorite craters, bottom surface is freshly broken and free of zap pits, is 3.87 b.y. old and has been exposed on the surface to cosmic rays for only ~ 4.5 m.y.
is aluminous in composition, with relative high trace element content; found to contain substantial Ni, Ir and Au. The Pb/Pb age of 60335 was determined to be 4.08 b.y.
coated with black glass on one side and is thought to be ejecta from South Ray Crater
known as "Big Muley"; named after Bill Muehlberger, the leader of the Apollo 16 field geology team
an ancient regolith breccia that became a closed system about 3.9 b.y. ago; and has a few zap pits

This surface sample was collected 10 meters Northeast of the rim of Plum crater as part of a radial sample sequence (with 61180, 61500, and 61140). It was collected from a spot disturbed by a footprint. The site is level with fragments <2 cm common and >2 cm sparse. A .75 m boulder is 2 meters north of the sample.

Innermost of a radial sample sequence with 61500, 61160, and 61140. The site is level until there is a break at Plum crater, fragments <2 cm are common, >10 cm are sparse. Craters <10 cm are dense and craters <1 meter are common. Some of the larger craters are subdued and some are sharp.
coherent, medium grey breccia with a glassy matrix and abundant clasts; zap pits are surrounded with wide spall zones
small chip of white material covered with chalky-white dust on most sides

Soil color is listed as light olive gray but mission transcripts state, "I just had a good scoopful, and I lost it. Let me dig out a little - another little trench. There she be. Coming up all white. That's all that's in there John."
friable light matrix breccia with both light and dark clasts; rounded and has many zap pits
very friable, chalky white rock that broke up into powder during handling in curatorial labs and has not been adequately studied.

The sample area is on the south slope of Buster crater, fragments are mostly 5 cm or less, and craters are mostly 5-10 cm. There was a light colored material on the surface of the soil, but none of this high albedo material was found below the surface.
is the residue from the bag that was used to return rock sample 62295 and may or may not be a proper soil sample
63320 is probably the fine grained ejecta from North Ray crater. If Shadow Rock was ejected from North Ray crater, these samples have been virtually undisturbed since the North Ray event.
part anorthosite and part impact melt; most surfaces have micrometeorite craters, indicating it had once been a surface sample
thick shiny black glass coat on one side and numerous micrometeorite pits on the other
egg-shaped object about 5 cm long and 3 cm across almost completely covered with thick black glass

Surface soil 64800 accompanies rake 64810, collected at Station 4B . Blocks and cobbles cover 80-90% of the northeast wall of the main crater, elsewhere the surface is relatively smooth with scattered cobbles. The fines are loose, numerous small crates are found in the sample area.
hollow, broken sphere or glass bubble about 3 - 4 cm in size. The glass surface is smooth and without zap pits, and has a green color.
"chalky white chunk" neatly tucked between the regolith breccia and the black glass coat; friable white matrix with large grey breccia clasts

Soil 65500 accompanies rake sample 65510. The sample area has no blocks larger tha 30 cm, it is a mostly sandy surface. The fines are loose with a gray surface and whitish subsurface. Numerous small craters are superposed on the 20 meter crater. Friable clods are included in the sample.
a very mature soil with average grain size of 85 microns
very mature soil and has an average grain size of 85 microns
one of several dense particles found in soil sample 65901
66030 is a soil collected with an 8 cm breccia. It is supposed that the breccia is local ejecta, but the source crater is not obvious.
regolith breccia, but has excess 40Ar and has been termed "ancient regolith breccia".

Soils 66040 and 66030 and breccia 66055 were collected at the same location at Station 6. It is supposed that the breccia is local ejecta, but the source crater is not obvious. In the sample area 15-30 cm blocks are relatively common, soil is relatively firm compared to the looser regolith at Stations 4 and 5. Craters in the area are mostly <5 meters.
an indurated clod of white impact ejecta; possibly from South Ray crater.
67016 is a feldspathic fragmental breccia with both light and dark clasts, and is 3.95 b.y. old with an exposure age of 50 m.y.
a glass-coated basaltic impact melt or "bomb" that has not been dated.
glass coat is rather thick, but has been fractured and broken off by micrometeorite bombardment
67235 is a large special sample that was collected to study the outer surface of a lunar rock.
grey matrix breccias with both dark and light clasts
chosen as a "reference soil" for the "lunar highland initiative" and is not greatly different from other soil samples from North Ray Crater
noticeably coarser grain size and less mature compared with other lunar soils probably due to the fact that NRC is only 50 m.y. old

67628 was renumbered by Ryder and Norman (1980) when they made the catalog. It is a collection of four "glass bombs" that were collected as rake samples from just inside the rim of North Ray Crater. 67628 was originally cataloged as 4 glass particles, but Ryder and Norman (1980) treated them as separate particles - so they were renumbered.

67628 was renumbered by Ryder and Norman (1980) when they made the catalog. It is a collection of four "glass bombs" that were collected as rake samples from just inside the rim of North Ray Crater. 67628 was originally cataloged as 4 glass particles, but Ryder and Norman (1980) treated them as separate particles - so they were renumbered.

67628 was renumbered by Ryder and Norman (1980) when they made the catalog. It is a collection of four "glass bombs" that were collected as rake samples from just inside the rim of North Ray Crater. 67628 was originally cataloged as 4 glass particles, but Ryder and Norman (1980) treated them as separate particles - so they were renumbered.

67628 was renumbered by Ryder and Norman (1980) when they made the catalog. It is a collection of four "glass bombs" that were collected as rake samples from just inside the rim of North Ray Crater. 67628 was originally cataloged as 4 glass particles, but Ryder and Norman (1980) treated them as separate particles - so they were renumbered.

Borchardt et al. (1985) and Stoffler et al. (1985) studied glass particles from North Ray Crater and labeled these particles "glass bombs". 67629 was originally 4 pieces, which have since been relabeled 67629, 67695, 67696 and 67697

Borchardt et al. (1985) and Stoffler et al. (1985) studied glass particles from North Ray Crater and labeled these particles "glass bombs". 67629 was originally 4 pieces, which have since been relabeled 67629, 67695, 67696 and 67697

Borchardt et al. (1985) and Stoffler et al. (1985) studied glass particles from North Ray Crater and labeled these particles "glass bombs". 67629 was originally 4 pieces, which have since been relabeled 67629, 67695, 67696 and 67697
shielded soil from E-W split in House Rock
immature soils from the rim of fresh North Ray Crater. House Rock and other samples of North Ray Crater are breccias
micropoikilitic impact breccia
are glass (?) particles with zaps
a "walnut" from soil 67941; Granulitic Breccia
plagioclase-rich, ophitic basalt with igneous texture
heterogeneous breccia which is welded together by flow-banded glass; appears to be an orange stain on the surface; unusual area of very vesicular melt on one end

68415 and 68416 have an igneous has an intersertal texture characterized by a "fret work" of plagioclase laths with interstitial olivine and pyroxene and minor occurances of opaques, phosphates, residual glass and other minerals; is 3.76 b.y.

has an igneous has an intersertal texture characterized by a "fret work" of plagioclase laths with interstitial olivine and pyroxene and minor occurances of opaques, phosphates, residual glass and other minerals

Soil 68500 accompanied rake sample 68510 at Station 8, on the north rim of a 10-15 meter crater in the vicinity of visible rays from South Ray crater. Astronauts reported several glass fragments scattered over the surface in this area, some reflecting red and green in the sunlight. The sample area is generally free of large rocks.
mature soil and should be compared with sample 68841, collected nearby.
coarse fine
coherent, grey, aphanitic rocks
coherent, grey, aphanitic rocks
coherent, grey, aphanitic rocks
Drive Tube is unopened and has been in vacuum since it was sealed in CSVC on the moon.
apparently a polymict breccia that is texturally inhomogeneous and has a large white clast

69940 is a "scoop" sample from several cm below the surface. Large fragments are relatively sparse at the sample site, surface is relatively firm, craters 5-30 cm are common but larger ones are sparse.
appears to be more mafic than most poikilitic Apollo 16 breccias and has only minor clasts

69960 was collected at Station 9 from under a .5 meter boulder after it had been rolled over. It is part of a "surface sampler" including soils 69920, 69940, and 69960 and fragments 69003, 69004, and 66935. Large fragments are relatively sparse at the sample site, surface is relatively firm, craters 5-30 cm are common but larger ones are sparse.
